image.title: DW.COM
image.description: News, Analysis and Service from Germany and Europe - in 30 Languages

item.title: Canada approves contentious expansion of crude oil pipeline
item.description: Canada has once again approved a contentious pipeline expansion that would allow the nation to diversify oil markets. The new pipeline has drawn criticism from environmental groups who fear spills.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Trump begins 2020 US presidential election campaign with Florida rally
item.description: The president talked tariffs and his former rivals in his first official rally for the 2020 election. He used the speech to position himself as a Washington outsider, two and half years into his presidential term.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Ex-UEFA boss Michel Platini freed after questioning over 2022 World Cup
item.description: Michel Platini has been released from custody after being questioned over the awarding of the 2022 FIFA World Cup to Qatar. The ex-UEFA president was one of the members who voted for the decision.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Germany: 670 kilograms of heroin seized at Polish border
item.description: German authorities have seized a record amount of smuggled heroin at the German-Polish border. The drugs were said to be worth upwards of €50 million on the street.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Domestic violence against men – German states move to break taboos
item.description: For the first time ever, two German states are launching an initiative to help male victims of domestic violence. Officials in Bavaria and North Rhine-Westphalia say they want to break the taboos surrounding the topic.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Brazil's Marta overtakes Miroslav Klose as leading World Cup scorer
item.description: She's a six-time world player of the year and has now scored 17 World Cup goals, but Marta has never won women's football's biggest prize. Judging by the competition in Group C, that could be a tall order this year too.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Germany's Siemens to cut 2,700 jobs
item.description: Siemens has announced massive job cuts in its power generation division as it seeks to make cost savings. The industrial giant is undertaking a major restructuring with the aim of cutting more than €2 billion in costs.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Throngs attend Trump's official 2020 re-election kickoff in Florida
item.description: Thousands of adoring fans are in Orlando for what they say will be a historical event. Though his re-election campaign began the day he took office, the rally marks its official beginning in a must-win state.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Mexico's AMLO faces first major crisis after US immigration deal
item.description: Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador's presidency has hit a wall. An immigration agreement he struck with the United States is under fire from his own party, and has damaged his popularity in Mexico.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Boris Johnson pulls ahead in Tory leadership race
item.description: Ex-foreign secretary Boris Johnson has surged ahead of his rivals in the second poll of Tory leadership race. Moderate Rory Stewart survived against the odds.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: EU delays accession talks with N. Macedonia and Albania
item.description: EU ministers have decided to delay opening accession talks with Albania and North Macedonia. Germany was partly to blame for the hold up.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Opinion: German politician's murder is an attack on democracy
item.description: Politician Walter Lübcke may have been murdered by a right-wing extremist. If that turns out to be the case, the killer was targeting the heart of Germany's democratic system, says DW's Marcel Fürstenau.
item.dc:subject: Opinion

item.title: EU Commission finds national climate plans insufficient
item.description: The EU executive has said national plans for renewables and energy efficiency fell short of the bloc's goals. The deficiency may undermine its ability to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 40% compared to 1990 levels.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: ECB hints at more stimulus as global economy outlook dims
item.description: If eurozone inflation stays low, the European Central Bank (ECB) could cut interest rates even further and take other steps to boost it, ECB chief Mario Draghi said. The remark prompted accusations from Donald Trump.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Myopic stock markets deter green investments
item.description: Companies remain torn between making socially responsible investments and meeting the short-term expectations of the stock market. But it's not all gloom and doom for green investors, especially in Europe.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Russian YouTuber explores the horrors of Stalin's gulags
item.description: A strong majority of Russians approve of Stalin's rule, and young adults have never heard of his Great Terror campaign. Now YouTube star Yury Dud's film about the legacy of Stalinist repressions is shaking the country.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Blogger Bilal Khan's murder spotlights fragile free speech in Pakistan
item.description: The recent killing of a young Pakistani blogger, known for criticizing the nation's powerful military, has once again reignited the debate about the deteriorating freedom of expression in the country.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Ebola: 'WHO between a rock and a hard place'
item.description: Declaring a global health emergency could galvanize aid to fight the Ebola epidemic in the DR Congo. It could also make the job of containing the virus much more difficult. The WHO's decision proved controversial.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Merkel backs Ukraine's Zelenskiy in Russia dispute
item.description: The Ukrainian president has vowed to push his country towards EU and NATO accession. German Chancellor Angela Merkel has backed his calls for maintaining sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Berlin to freeze rents for five years
item.description: Renters are increasingly unable to afford housing in Berlin. An influential property-owners' association has called for landlords to raise rents before the bill can go into effect.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Japan ends tsunami alert after earthquake
item.description: Japan officials lifted a tsunami warning for the country's northwest coast, following a strong earthquake in the area. Only a small wave ended up reaching the shore.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Germany says there is 'strong evidence' Iran behind tanker attacks
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel has said there is "strong evidence" Iran carried out attacks on two tankers in the Gulf of Oman. She also warned Iran of consequences if it violated the 2015 international nuclear deal.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Germany probes 'right-wing extremist' murder of politician
item.description: A politician has been murdered in an apparent execution-style assassination. German Interior Minister Horst Seehofer has described the attack as "right-wing extremist" in nature, saying it was "directed against us all."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Brazilian photographer Sebastiao Salgado wins German book trade Peace Prize
item.description: The prestigious Peace Prize of the German Book Trade has been awarded to 75-year-old Brazilian photographer Sebastiao Salgado for raising awareness about environmental destruction and the climate crisis.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Facebook's cryptocurrency plan is taking shape
item.description: The world's biggest social network has indicated that it wants to move into the payments industry by launching its own cryptocurrency next year. DW looks at what's behind Facebook's not-so-cryptic plan.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Joshua Wong: Carrie Lam 'incapable' of leading Hong Kong
item.description: Speaking to DW, activist Joshua Wong said the city's Chief Executive Lam must step down following orders to shoot at people protesting the extradition law. Lam's attitude is also symptomatic of China's interference.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Hong Kong leader refuses to step down after mass protests
item.description: Carrie Lam, the city's chief executive, has said she wants time to "continue to work hard" for the people of Hong Kong. But activists have promised to not back down, with Joshua Wong telling DW: "Now is the time."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Germany's imam quandary: Educate, don't import
item.description: Ending foreign influence on Muslim religious leaders' education is a long-term goal for the German government. A new study might lead the way for training local imams, if all parties involved are willing to participate.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: German philosopher Jürgen Habermas at 90
item.description: Renowned for his analysis of democracy and rule of law, he is one of the most influential thinkers alive. As he turns 90, Jürgen Habermas is not about to stop getting involved in the big questions of our time.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Dead or alive: A Peruvian market where the illegal animal trade thrives
item.description: If you know where to look at Peru's infamous rainforest market, you'll find all sorts of endangered animals for sale as bushmeat or as pets. But some are trying to stop the trade before it's too late.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Germany mulls requests to host Sea-Watch migrants
item.description: Dozens of cities, including Berlin and Rottenburg, have offered to take in migrants rescued in the Mediterranean. But German authorities have said resettling 53 migrants rescued by Sea-Watch would require EU support.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Migrants in the Gulf see dreams of higher wages ruined
item.description: More than a million foreign workers have been sent packing as Gulf leaders face pressure to hire more locals. Despite the region's reputation for exploitation and rigidity, many foreigners still dream of Arabia.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: EU court rules against autobahn tolls
item.description: The ECJ has rejected the fees known as "vignettes" after Austria, with support from the Netherlands, had lodged a complaint. The EU has said the German concept for the fees breaches anti-discrimination laws.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Women in football's boardrooms: Alone among men
item.description: Despite on-field progress, 95 percent of football's leadership roles are filled by men. Many clubs and associations resist quotas aimed at changing that, but Norway's example shows there's another way.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Germany: Police find newborn baby in garbage
item.description: The child was close to death after being discovered wrapped in towels in a trash sack. Police said the mother had disposed of the newborn shortly after she gave birth to it on Friday.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: 'Ignoring' anti-Semitism not an option, German president warns
item.description: President Frank-Walter Steinmeier has appealed for Germans to show civic courage in the face of anti-Semitism. The call comes amid growing attacks on Jewish people in Germany.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Women's World Cup: Germany find their shooting boots just before the knockouts
item.description: Germany have qualified for the knockout stages after coming through Group B unbeaten and without conceding a single goal. Monday's 4-0 win over South Africa was welcome but routine. Now there are bigger tests to come.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Women's World Cup: Germany hammer South Africa to secure top spot
item.description: Having already booked their place in the Round of 16, Germany were out to clinch top spot in Group B. They did so in formidable fashion against a South Africa side that struggled to keep up.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: EU warns against blaming Iran for oil tanker attacks
item.description: European foreign ministers have urged restraint in directing blame over an alleged attack on oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman. The US has pointed the finger at Iran, but European diplomats say they need more evidence.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Exhibition 'This Place' shows Israel and the West Bank from a new perspective
item.description: The images we know of Israel and the West Bank very often portray conflict. An exhibition at the Jewish Museum Berlin features works of photographers who explored the area with an artistic approach.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Women are less visible in STEM: Why?
item.description: According to common stereotypes, women are better at languages and history, while men are better at chemistry and math. But are these categorizations based on fact?
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Germany, France and Spain sign deal on European fighter jet
item.description: German Defense Minister Ursula von der Leyen has described the signing as a "big day for the European defense union." The 'Future Combat Air System' is due to be operational by 2040.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: India-US trade tensions threaten the ties that bind
item.description: The US and India are long-standing allies, and trade is an important part of the relationship. However, a row over market access and tariffs has escalated, leading to fears of a protracted dispute.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Iran prepares to violate uranium limit in nuclear deal
item.description: The Islamic Republic has signaled its intention to exceed limits on uranium enrichment under the deal. Iranian officials said European guarantors still have time to save the accord before it surpasses "the 300 kg limit."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Fake lashes with side effects: Risk of eczema and infection
item.description: Long, full lashes are considered attractive, especially in women. That's why artificial lashes are on the rise. But these extensions come with health risks.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Bonn's Schumannfest: Pianist Danae Dörken on the power of music
item.description: Hailed as one of the rising stars of her generation, the 27-year-old German-Greek pianist is also a festival organizer. She tells DW why artistry fulfills an essential function in people's lives.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: France to declare natural emergency after deadly storm
item.description: The French government is to declare a natural emergency for farming areas in the southeast blasted by a fierce storm at the weekend. A German tourist was one of those killed when her caravan was hit by a tree.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Deutsche Bank may create 'bad bank' for high-risk assets
item.description: Germany's largest lender is planning to isolate up to €50 billion in high-risk assets, reported the Financial Times. The bank's chief executive has vowed to restore sustainable profitability to the ailing lender.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Australian police 'baffled' by Belgian teen's disappearance
item.description: An 18-year-old Belgian backpacker has gone missing from the coastal holiday town of Byron Bay in Australia. Police said his disappearance is "out of character" and homicide has not been ruled out.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Dane becomes Germany's first foreign mayor
item.description: Claus Ruhe Madsen has now become the first non-German citizen to govern a German city after being elected mayor of Rostock. The Danish national presented himself as pragmatic and environmentally conscious.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: How will the far-right AfD party shape the European Parliament?
item.description: Germany's right-wing populist AfD party will only have limited influence in the European Parliament. But its lawmakers hope to learn from more seasoned populist leaders.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: East Germany's Görlitz elects CDU mayor over AfD challenger in runoff vote
item.description: Germany's populist AfD party lost a key mayoral race in Görlitz, where all mainstream parties united behind a Romanian-born CDU candidate Octavian Ursu. AfD's Sebastian Wippel said his own result was still "great."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: In Duisburg, China expands trade influence in Germany
item.description: As one of the end points for China's vast new global trade route, the former industrial city of Duisburg is well known to many Chinese businesses. Many Duisburg residents are optimistic about Beijing's growing influence.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: France launches national civic service for youth
item.description: Two decades after France ended conscription, the government has launched a program targeting young people. The government is hoping to "increase the cohesion and resilience of the nation" with the service.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Copy of Charles Darwin's 'Origin of Species' sells for record half million
item.description: A presentation copy of Charles Darwin's "Origin of Species" has sold for $500,075 — double the amount expected. The book was originally owned by German botanist Robert Caspary, who received the book from Darwin.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: The long road to being a pro footballer
item.description: Germany's youth teams have been having trouble qualifying for major international tournaments in recent years. So what is at the root of the problem and what is being done to try to correct the issue?
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Italian director Franco Zeffirelli dead at 96
item.description: Famed for opulent film and opera productions, Zeffirelli led a storied life and often courted controversy. He died Saturday in Rome.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Berlin's Club der Visionäre damaged in blaze
item.description: Club der Visionäre, a well-known party spot in Berlin's Kreuzberg district, has been partially gutted by a fire, authorities said. Emergency responders managed to stop the blaze before it reached a nearby gas station.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Exiled Turkish journalist Can Dundar reunited with family in Germany after 3 years
item.description: Can Dundar has been reunited with his family in Berlin after his wife managed to flee Turkey. The well-known journalist has been in living in exile in Germany since 2016.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Director of Jewish Museum Berlin resigns
item.description: The director of the Jewish Museum Berlin, Peter Schäfer, has resigned following criticism from the Central Council of Jews. At issue were a museum exhibition and a tweet seen to be critical of Israel's occupation policy.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Women's World Cup: Lena Oberdorf – The 17-year-old student learning fast
item.description: Her coach says she's "fantastic," and Lena Oberdorf has made made her mark at the World Cup while taking time out from school. With Germany through to round of 16, she could enhance her reputation against South Africa.
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: German doctors convicted over abortion law
item.description: The doctors were found to have broken a regulation that forbids describing how an abortion is performed. Campaigners have argued that lack of access to information is a health and rights issue.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Art Basel: Small galleries are dying despite art market boom
item.description: The Art Basel is one of the top-selling international art fairs. Yet among the record-breaking sales, not all dealers are profiting from the hype.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: When smart devices pass secrets to the police
item.description: It may crackdown on crime — and privacy, too. That's if German police get powers to seize personal data on smart devices. Germany's discussing plans that are already a reality in the USA.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: The Strait of Hormuz: The world's most important oil choke point
item.description: Following a number of oil tanker blasts in the Gulf of Oman, tensions between the United States and Iran are rising further. DW takes a closer look at what role the Strait of Hormuz plays for global oil supplies.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Blood donation: Everything you've ever needed to know
item.description: Can cigarette smokers donate blood? Am I going to pass out? Can I drink booze afterwards? Should I eat beforehand? Am I old enough? Here's everything you ever wanted to know about blood donation on World Blood Donor Day.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Rediscover East Germany's top fashion magazine, 'Sibylle'
item.description: An exhibition in Berlin showcases "Sibylle," an East German fashion and culture magazine that for decades offered women in the communist state more than dress patterns.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Germany records significant drop in weapons exports in 2018
item.description: The annual Weapons Export Report registered a 23% drop compared with 2017 according to media sources. The government says the decrease is a sign of Germany's "restrictive and responsible weapons export policy."
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Trump's troop talk again rattles Germany's security assumptions
item.description: US President Donald Trump announced the US will send upward of 1,000 troops to Poland. The plan was light on details, but Trump said he knew where the forces would come from: Germany. Berlin's reaction is mixed.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: US loses billions as Chinese tourists stay away over trade war
item.description: The number of arrivals from China to the US fell last year for the first time in 15 years. The Chinese are the world's highest-spending foreign visitors and their tourism dollar is sorely missed.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: From 'Tintin' to 'Lucky Luke': What makes Belgian comics so successful?
item.description: Belgian comic heroes like Lucky Luke and the Smurfs enjoy worldwide recognition. But what makes Belgium the No.1 producer of European comics? Can Dickie and Co. make it on the international stage?
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: What does Berlin have that NYC doesn't?
item.description: The legendary image of Berlin as a free-spirited domain where underground culture thrives has attracted a great number of expats. But some New Yorkers are coming to the city to find another type of freedom.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Climate action: Can we change the climate from the grassroots up?
item.description: The past couple of years will likely go down in history as the ones when climate change really hit. They could also be remembered as the ones in which people worked to stop it. DW looks at some civil society victories.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Europe's plastic waste sent home in toxic row
item.description: Europe’s sustainability practices are world-leading, but some believe that what has passed as recycling should actually be called liabilityshifting. DW spoke with an American who plans to change all that.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Natural high: Brazil's Guarana growers ditch chemicals for ancient knowledge
item.description: For the Guarana growers of the Amazon, the caffeine-rich berries aren't just a fortifying brew but part of ancient tradition that respects their rainforest home.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Opening of Berlin's ambitious Humboldt Forum museum project delayed
item.description: Housed in Berlin's reconstructed Prussian palace, the Humboldt Forum was planning to open exhibitions this year to mark the 250th birthday of Alexander von Humboldt. But like Berlin's new airport, everything is on hold.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: 25 years of Bonn's history museum: Postwar Germany portrayed through objects
item.description: The Haus der Geschichte in Bonn, one of Germany's most popular museums, opened 25 years ago. Beyond pieces of the Berlin Wall, here's why a dentist's chair is among the exhibits of its permanent exhibition.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: René Pollesch to head Berlin's iconic Volksbühne
item.description: The 56-year-old playwright and director will be the new director of Berlin's Volksbühne, Culture Senator Klaus Lederer confirmed on Wednesday. It's hoped that Pollesch will end years of turbulence at the theater.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Tips for apartment hunting and moving in Germany
item.description: Roughly 8 million Germans move house every year. So what's it like? DW's Cristina Burack shares some quirks of finding a new place to live in Germany, and learns that Germans are not afraid to be hands-on in the process.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Rammstein singer Till Lindemann under investigation for assault
item.description: The heavy metal front man is accused of beating a 54-year-old man from Hamburg in a hotel bar. Witnesses have said that the man was insulting him before the physical altercation began.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: 'Chernobyl' creator asks tourists to show respect at disaster site
item.description: Television show maker Craig Mazin reminded visitors to the exclusion zone in Ukraine that "a terrible tragedy occured there." Tour operators have reported a huge spike in interest after the release of the miniseries.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Caught between floods and drought: Farmers in Nicaragua living in uncertainty
item.description: Across the Central American Dry Corridor, communities are facing increasingly extreme weather. In Nicaragua, the region's poorest country, subsistence farmers like Blanca Landero Betarco face a daily battle.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Radiohead makes stolen tracks available to help 'Extinction Rebellion'
item.description: The band has reacted in unusual fashion to a ransom notice over 18 hours of hacked material. Rather than pay hackers, the group has put the tracks online and asked fans to donate to Extinction Rebellion.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Anne Frank's incomplete novel 'Dear Kitty' published
item.description: The Jewish girl who became posthumously famous with her diary also hoped to publish a novel. The unfinished work of the Holocaust victim — who would have turned 90 on June 12 — has been released in German.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Germany's 'gay' Paragraph 175 abolished 25 years ago
item.description: When Paragraph 175 of the German Penal Code was abolished 25 years ago, homosexuality ceased to be separately regulated. DW takes a look back at a history of persecution in West and East Germany.
item.dc:subject: Germany

item.title: Stasi's pervasive footprint across two Berlins revealed
item.description: In the former prison where the East German secret police locked up dissidents, a museum has painstakingly mapped the vast web of locations through which the Stasi carried out social control — and planned coups.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Germany: Gay conversion 'therapy' ban presented
item.description: "Homosexuality is not a disease and does not require treatment," said Health Minister Jens Spahn. In Germany, there are an estimated 1,000 attempts a year to change the sexual orientation of gay people, say critics.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: Carl Hagenbeck: The inventor of the modern animal park
item.description: No bars, no high fences: It's thanks to Carl Hagenbeck that most zoos today look that way. June 10 marks his 175th birthday. But he also had other controversial ideas for his parks: exhibiting humans as well.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Heiko Maas in Tehran: Why Germany can't concede too much to Iran
item.description: German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas has held talks with his Iranian counterpart, Javad Zarif, in Tehran, in a bid to ease tensions in the Persian Gulf. But experts say the visit is unlikely to produce any breakthrough.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: FIFA Women's World Cup: Why Germany has a unique football vocabulary
item.description: It doesn't feel that way now, but Germans weren't enthusiastic about football in the 19th century. Christoph Marx, a World Cup historian, explains how special terms for soccer were developed to change that.
item.dc:subject: Culture

item.title: Ampaire test-flies world's biggest electric plane
item.description: The American aircraft maker has launched its Ampaire 337, the largest hybrid-electric aircraft ever flown. With commercial use beckoning for 2021, it's a step in the direction of reducing carbon footprints in the sky.
item.dc:subject: Business

item.title: Alzheimer's and tooth brushing: Forget to brush today, forget a lot more later?
item.description: You may be able to fool your partner with a mint and some mouthwash (please stop doing that, though, it's gross), but your rancid tooth brushing habits could catch up with you later in life.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Lea Schüller: The goals to lead Germany to glory
item.description: Easygoing and dangerous in front of goal: the young striker is the new hope for Germany ahead of the Women's World Cup in France. Can her goals lead Germany to the title in France this summer?
item.dc:subject: Sports

item.title: Kids in Germany to name exoplanet, star
item.description: German schools, kindergartens and amateur astronomers have been asked to come up with names for two heavenly bodies. The huge exoplanet and its star currently go by the unpoetical catalog numbers HD 32518 and HD 32518b.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: European Drug Report 2019 directly contrasts US drug crisis, tells a story of relative calm
item.description: Around 8,200 people died of an overdose in Europe in 2018, according to the European Drug Report. That's almost 10 times less than the number of overdose deaths in the United States.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Berlin takes a new approach to the Three Seas Initiative
item.description: Germany is begun to show support for the eastern European initiative. President Steinmeier is traveling to Ljubljana to meet with the group, as the region has come into the geopolitical focus of major powers.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: The war widows protecting Sri Lanka's mangroves
item.description: Sri Lankan women who lost husbands in the country's 25-year conflict are now protecting the country's mangroves — and combating gender stereotypes in the process.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Ebola cases in DR Congo top 2,000
item.description: The daily number of new Ebola cases has tripled in recent months, according to aid organizations. Local distrust and armed groups have hampered a response to the world's second-largest Ebola epidemic.
item.dc:subject: News

item.title: German doctors want human egg donations to be legalized
item.description: A group of doctors in Germany is calling for new reproductive health laws. They say the current legislation is outdated, as the science has moved on. They want human egg donations to be legalized and to make IVF safer.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Italy: Taranto residents rise up to stop air pollution claiming local lives
item.description: Parents in the southern Italian city of Taranto are taking on the Arcelor Mittal Italia steelworks they say is polluting the air and killing their children.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Mexicans turn to ancient Aztec floating gardens to revive mangrove forests
item.description: In Mexico City, old Aztec floating gardens are still used to grow food. Now, environmentalists think this ancient technology could help restore a coastal ecosystem — and help fishermen in the process.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Swedes switch to trains due to global warming
item.description: Swedes seem to be following climate activist Greta Thunberg's example in shunning air travel. The percentage that opted to take a train rather than fly has doubled in a year and a half. Flight shame may be at work.
item.dc:subject: World

item.title: Forbidden fruit: The curious early history of apples
item.description: As mundane as the apple may seem, its history involves enormous animals, the Ice Age, the Silk Road and a huge role in the stories we tell.
item.dc:subject: Science

item.title: Restoring forests in Mali: Tree stumps could be the solution to disappearing woodlands
item.description: As people fell trees to get wood for cooking, Mali's trees are disappearing at rapid speed. A reforestation expert who has been dubbed 'the forest maker' is working with farmers to restore the country's woodlands.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Government must involve residents in cleanup of Nairobi rivers
item.description: In Kenya, local residents need to be involved in the restoration of the Nairobi River basin says guest commentator Sam Dindi, the co-founder of 'Mazingira yetu' magazine. It's the only way for a healthy future.
item.dc:subject: Environment

item.title: Kenya's herders adapt to drought with new land management deals
item.description: Droughts have left herders in Laikipia desperate to find pasture for their cattle, and brought them into conflict with landowners. But better land management is showing that these pastoralist communities can adapt.
item.dc:subject: Environment
